Author: .ayab
Content:
A coveted revered concept, a unifier of the ungovernable, long stand as the ultimate form of the great Indonesian project; is but an empty vessel that symbolize the hopes of our founder, yet its soul is empty with naught to seek its beauty.

Our language, the thing we have duty to maintain and guard against the progress of time, is slipping away from our grasp like loose sand in our hand.

We do not have a mold to cement them into something corporeal that can be the axis of our language saga and journey. No great figure like Shakespeare and tolkien to be coveted, to be look upon with envy and reverence, no epic and sagas that is formed by the culture we have. 

Our classes just stand empty, never highlighting with great concise the figure within our literature to be taught as example for our students to learn form. 

What is a structure for a language if it's garden is desolate without life. 

A great tragedy for our nation

Author: adi_onysus
Content:
We have words, yet few choose to mold them into lasting legacies. Our bookshelves gather dust while our eyes gleam at headlines, and they never linger long enough to even absorb the ideas to the depth of thought. The world no longer reads; it scrolls. Reading has never been a deeply ingrained habit amongst Indonesia's populace, and thus this decline is even more apparent.

Towering figure--Shakespeare, Mark Twain, Tolkien--have shaped English into what it is today. But our language lacks widely celebrated literary icons who praise its essence. Pramoedya, Sapardi, Chairil Anwar, these names remain unsung and not given the recognition they deserve. Our classrooms do not echo with their words, and so the students move on, unaware of the giants that walked before them, and even among them.

Perhaps this is simply the reality of our time. A world too fast, too fleeting, where the beauty of language is lost in the rush of information. But if a language is to endure beyond function--if it is to be more than just a means of speech--it must have its champions, its poets, its visionaries.

Author: .ayab
Content:
What seeks in the fleeting time to find meaning in our language? What sorrows been written, what love and emotion yet to hold us in awe for our long standing fascination towards the fleeting that is beautiful. Those, the one who seeks it's majesty their song yet sunged as heroes of our age, not given the accolades and tribute they deserving of. The minds and the life of our people could fill the largest libraries in the world and yet it won't be enough. To look upon the state of our language, our literature, is to look upon a desolate place while a verdant garden is maintained and cherished next to you.

Great envy has already risen within me everytime i see how they, our enemies and foes, has been the gardener of their own roots, while we, famished with nothing to harvest.

When you said that the time for wonder of literature time to be forged and made already gone and never to return, I can't help but to hold out tears in my eyes, for your words are true and painful to admit

Author: .ayab
Content:
And questions for the ages: how do we flame the passion to write in our language? To celebrate our culture and way of mind with no restraint.

To loom upon theaters as it it filled with eager watchers proud of their people creations.

To be proud of your language, to bragg it towards the world as you cherish all of its whole.

A love for the imagination of our people, a devotion towards more of its creation and evolution

Author: .ayab
Content:
Yet time is cruel

What can you naught but do but just watch with great torment as the foundation of our very republic destroyed brick-by-brick

Author: nerosalt
Content:
A stomach without food? A horse without hay? A mule without its carrot?

The simple ability to read is meaningless when you keep it as that.

Poets like Shelley and Keats, and Poe and legends like Dylan Thomas, to avant-garde icons such as Mayakovsky, even writers like Lovecraft and Orwell, one thing differentiates them from your disgraceful Tribune writer.
In the words they write, they carve a shard of their very soul into the thin paper. In every sentence a emotion, feeling, frozen in time. A memory, a window into their minds. Each letter piercing our skulls, painting a sight greater than what our eyes can see.
From the Fields of Elysium to the horrors beyond our comprehension, the words are more than mere shapes on a sheet of wood.

Author: .ayab
Content:
"YOLO," said Millennials, and "yeet," the Zoomers cried
"Rizzler gyatt fanum tax," the Alphas then replied
And lo, there came a shaking as an ebon spire rose
Upon it writ the tongues of men, their generations' prose
And from the sky a thund'rous voice called out unto the stone,
As golden letters glowed upon its surface, newly shown:
"RIZZLER GYATT FANUM TAX, SIGMA OHIO SKIBIDI"
And all beheld the words embossed theron in great timidity
With shaking and with wavering voice, the grim refrain began
As all the generations sang the verse at its command
Their weeping and their running sores did nothing to delay
The chanting of that fevered song as night succumbed to day
But rose that morn a blighted sun whose light scoured like a flood
The sky was rent asunder and the rivers turned to blood
Their flesh peeled off in sickly strips, their bones were rendered bare
And still they chanted ever on, the words they uttered there
Until bone and flesh and earth and death were all forgotten things
And still unbidden, undesired, the blackened spire sings
Around it wind the whispers of the souls in its captivity:
"rizzler gyatt fanum tax... sigma ohio skibidi".
